repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
## Problem:
Scanning the filesystem is expensive and particularly affects startuptime.

## Solution:

Reduce the amount of redundant directory scans.

Change `DoInRuntimeCB` to be able to handle multiple matches so callbacks can sort and prioritize.

comment_data.body: perhaps `expand_wildcards_and_source` ? This usecase seems to be the implied one given that it hardcodes matching of .vim then .lua files
This is also called with `add_pack_start_dir` and `add_start_pack_plugin` which in those cases the first two loops (for `.lua` and `.vim`) don't do anything.
Modifying the signature of `DoInRuntimepathCB` to support multiple files seems to be a better route.

Just to be clear: the ordering "Vim first, then Lua" is now fully taken care of by `runtime!`? Otherwise you need to interleave Vim and Lua files as in #24147.

(also check `ftplugin.vim` and `indent.vim`, cf. #23202)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -48,8 +48,10 @@ fun! s:SynSet()
     " load each in sequence.  Skip empty entries.
     for name in split(s, '\.')
       if !empty(name)
-        exe "runtime! syntax/" . name . ".vim syntax/" . name . "/*.vim"
-        exe "runtime! syntax/" . name . ".lua syntax/" . name . "/*.lua"
+        exe printf(
+          \ "runtime! syntax/%s.vim syntax/%s/*.vim  syntax/%s.lua syntax/%s/*.lua",
+          \ name, name, name, name
+          \ )

comment_data.body: Oh, and do these changes also apply to `nvim__get_runtime`? Could try using this instead of `runtime!` here, then.

comment_data.body:
Note, this is now the same style that `ftplugin.vim` does **currently**. Not sure if that was intentional:

```vim
      " When there is a dot it is used to separate filetype names.  Thus for
      " "aaa.bbb" load "aaa" and then "bbb".
      for name in split(s, '\.')
        " Load Lua ftplugins after Vim ftplugins _per directory_
        " TODO(clason): use nvim__get_runtime when supports globs and modeline
        exe printf('runtime! ftplugin/%s.vim ftplugin/%s.lua', name, name)
        exe printf('runtime! ftplugin/%s_*.vim ftplugin/%s_*.lua', name, name)
        exe printf('runtime! ftplugin/%s/*.vim ftplugin/%s/*.lua', name, name)
      endfor
```

Need to double-check how `:runtime` handles each argument; does each argument do a seperate scan(?).

comment_data.body:
Ok, currently each argument to `:runtime!` performs a separate scan, so the change in this file shouldn't do anything.

```vim
:runtime! a
:runtime! b
```
should be the same as
```vim
:runtime! a b
```

comment_data.body:
> Note, this is now the same style that `ftplugin.vim` does **currently**. Not sure if that was intentional:
> 
> ```viml
>       " When there is a dot it is used to separate filetype names.  Thus for
>       " "aaa.bbb" load "aaa" and then "bbb".
>       for name in split(s, '\.')
>         " Load Lua ftplugins after Vim ftplugins _per directory_
>         " TODO(clason): use nvim__get_runtime when supports globs and modeline
>         exe printf('runtime! ftplugin/%s.vim ftplugin/%s.lua', name, name)
>         exe printf('runtime! ftplugin/%s_*.vim ftplugin/%s_*.lua', name, name)
>         exe printf('runtime! ftplugin/%s/*.vim ftplugin/%s/*.lua', name, name)
>       endfor
> ```
> 
> Need to double-check how `:runtime` handles each argument; does each argument do a seperate scan(?).

No, the current state of `ftplugin.vim` is **wrong** (I messed up); #24147 should be the right behavior (I hope; still waiting for confirmation).

comment_data.body: This may change behavior if someone uses `:runtime!` to load alphabetically-sorted files (e.g. `00_foo.lua`, `10_foo.vim`, `20_foo.lua`, `30_foo.vim`). Not sure if anyone is using this with multiple extensions in the same pattern though.
could live in strings.c near `vim_strchr`
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -847,21 +844,46 @@ int source_in_path(char *path, char *name, int flags)
   return do_in_path_and_pp(path, name, flags, source_callback, NULL);
 }
 
-// Expand wildcards in "pat" and invoke do_source()/nlua_exec_file()
-// for each match.
-static void source_all_matches(char *pat)
+static bool str_ends_with(const char *str, const char *suffix)

comment_data.body: Ah yes. This changes the behavior of `:runtime! plugin/**/*.\(vim\|lua\)` to be the same as `:runtime! plugin/**/*.vim plugin/**/*.lua`.
I assumed that was intentional. Otherwise all of these `do_source` calls could be in a single for-loop.

I think this behavior change needs to be documented at `:h :runtime`. Although the old behavior is not used in Nvim itself, it possible that one may use it for some other purposes. To achieve the old behavior one has to expand the pattern and the source the files one by one.
In any case, we should decide and unambiguously document the order. (Which this PR is already improving.)

We don't want to lock down the implementation too much without good reason. I think all we need to be strict on is that any `foo/bar.vim` is loaded before `foo/bar.lua`. Anything outside of that should be explicitly undefined.

> I think all we need to be strict on is that any `foo/bar.vim` is loaded before `foo/bar.lua`.

This should still be documented at `:h runtime`, as previously `:runtime` doesn't have such special-cased behavior.

> We don't want to lock down the implementation too much without good reason. I think all we need to be strict on is that any `foo/bar.vim` is loaded before `foo/bar.lua`. Anything outside of that should be explicitly undefined.

Then we should document _that_. But I do think it's important to know whether `foo/bar.lua` is loaded before `foo/baz.vim` or not.
Added something to `:h runtime`.

As written, this kinda contradicts the sentence in `repeat.txt` -- here it sounds like "all vim files, then all lua files"?

I'd recommend writing one (longer) sentence and just copy-pasting it in both places, to make sure they're consistent.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -506,12 +506,12 @@ accordingly, proceeding as follows:
 
 10. Load the plugin scripts.					*load-plugins*
 	This does the same as the command: >
-		:runtime! plugin/**/*.vim
-		:runtime! plugin/**/*.lua
+		:runtime! plugin/**/*.\(vim\|lua\)
 <	The result is that all directories in 'runtimepath' will be searched
 	for the "plugin" sub-directory and all files ending in ".vim" or
 	".lua" will be sourced (in alphabetical order per directory),
-	also in subdirectories. First "*.vim" are sourced, then "*.lua" files.
+	also in subdirectories. First "*.vim" are sourced, then "*.lua" files,
+	per directory.

comment_data.body: Well currently this is what this PR implements, but yes, this needs to be a looser description to match what we have for `:runtime`.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
			For each {file} pattern, if both `.vim` and `.lua`
			files match in a directory, the `.vim` files take
			priority and are sourced first.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -231,6 +231,10 @@ For writing a Vim script, see chapter 41 of the user manual |usr_41.txt|.
 				:runtime plugin/**/*.vim
 <			would source the first file only.
 
+			For each {file} pattern, if a file has both a `.vim`
+			and `.lua` extensions, the `.vim` version will take
+			priority and be sourced first.

comment_data.body: This is stronger than what is intended. We just want to enforce that `foo/bar.vim` take priority over `foo/bar.lua`.

comment_data.body:
How about this
```suggestion
			For each {file} pattern, if a multiple matches differ
			only in extension, the `.vim` one takes the highest
			priority, the `.lua` one lower, and the others lowest.
```
"both a ... extensions" is a bit strange, isn't it?

```suggestion
  static const char *ftpat = "%s/ftdetect/*.{vim,lua}";  // NOLINT
```

```suggestion
  vim_snprintf(pat, len, "%s/plugin/**/*.{vim,lua}", ffname);  // NOLINT
```

```suggestion
    char *const plugin_pattern = "plugin/**/*.{vim,lua}";  // NOLINT
```
I've updated the change so the code doesn't rely on suffix patterns and the vim and lua case now has a specialized path.
Combine these two calls into one call with `DIP_START + DIP_OPT`
You haven't changed this to `source_callback_vim_lua`
ditto
What about `DIP_NORTP`? I don't fully understand what that flag does.
It should be removed.

```suggestion
			and `.lua` extensions, the `.vim` version will be sourced first.
```

"Priority" is whatever is sourced last, right (because it can overwrite decisions from what was sourced before)? So maybe it's less confusing to not mention priority here.

comment_data.body: is `source_in_path` needed anymore?
This isn't quite enough since if `x.vim`, `y.vim`, `x.lua` and `y.lua` are found then they are sourced in that order, as opposed to `x.vim`, `x.lua`, `y.vim`, `y.lua`.
Nope 😄

comment_regular_data.body: This essentially does *some* of the optimizations done in lazy.nvim.
Out of interest: does this affect (help solve) https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/23202 and friends?

Not sure. It does change things slightly.

Before if you had:
```
a/
    bar.vim
    baz.lua
b/
    qux.vim
    quux.lua
```

would be sourced in this order (all vim, then all lua):

```
a/bar.vim
b/aux.vim
a/baz.lua
b/quux.lua
```

with this PR:

```
a/bar.vim
a/baz.lua
b/qux.vim
b/quux.lua
```

There is still priority given to vim files, but this is done per directory.

> would be sourced in this order (all vim, the all lua):

I thought I fixed that... but on the higher level, so this change may indeed allow us to simplify the `runtime!` calls across the codebase.

> There is still priority given to vim files, but this is done per directory.

That is correct (or at least the documented behavior -- although the documentation is slightly ambiguous on whether it's _all_ Vim files alphabetically before _all_ Lua files alphabetically in a directory, or all files alphabetically, with Vim before Lua _per filename_).

> with this PR:
> 
> ```
> a/bar.vim
> a/baz.lua
> b/qux.vim
> b/quux.lua
> ```

I think such an example would be useful in the docs (in one place only) as this would obviate a need for a long explanation, but should include a `a/quux.vim` (so you can distinguish "per filename" and "per directory").

This is not behaviour we need/want to guarantee. In this example, the order these are sourced in is officially undefined, since they all have different names (even if it's implemented to do something defined).

Currently, we only want to guarantee:

    a/bar.vim
    a/bar.lua

Well, I don't think this was _intended_ to be "undefined behavior" -- this just happens to be "undocumented behavior", which is of course convenient for us since we can shrug our shoulders whenever someone complains. I don't think that's a good stance though. I do believe that at the least we should remark than any other order is not guaranteed (even if observed) and should not be relied on.

(We had enough confused reports about this which were unclear whether this was an issue.)

This PR is only intended to improve performance. Changes to documented behaviour that lock down implementation can be done in follow up PR's.

Just to note, lazy.nvim, which is what inspired this PR, doesn't give any priority to `.vim` files, but does source them alphabetically which means it prioritises lua files ([ref](https://github.com/folke/lazy.nvim/blob/5af331ea65418dc9361769891921fdee4bcc837a/lua/lazy/core/loader.lua#L410-L426)). Not a big problem, and easy to fix, but just pointing out that guaranteeing this behaviour doesn't give us much value, especially given the decline of vimscript.
Looks like there are some problems with this regexp: #24292
Sorry can you help me put one and one together? I don't fully follow.

This is probably worth a re-review.

I've now also reduced scans in `color/*` and `compiler/*`.

This lead to a behaviour change (bugfix?), where `compiler/*.lua` will now always be sourced, whereas before the presence of vim files would prevent this. However, this didn't make sense since `DIP_ALL` was passed which indicates all found files should be sourced.
Yes I noticed the bug with compiler before.

title: perf(rtp): reduce rtp scans
